Working position Position of load

Upper body upright, not twisted

Bending far forward with simultaneous twisting of trunk
Typical posture,position of load
When lifting, holding, carrying und lowering the load is close to body When lifting, holding, carrying und lowering load is near to medium to body Slightly bending forward with simultaneous twisting of trunk Load far from body <br shoulder
Working conditions
Good ergonomic conditions, e.g. sufficient space, no physical obstacles within the workspace, even level and solid flooring, sufficient lighting, good gripping conditions.
Space for movement restricted and unfavourable ergonomic conditions, e.g. 1: space for movement restricted by too low high or working area less than 1,5 m2 or 2: posture stability impaired by uneven floor or soft ground.
Strongly restricted space of movement and/or instability of centre of gravity of load, e.g. transfer of patients
Number on working day Total duration on working day Overall length \n on working day
Low load situation, physical overload unlikely to appear. Increased load situation, physical overload is possible for less resilent persons. For that group redesign of workplace is helpful. Highly increased load situation, physical overload also possible for normal persons. Redesign of the workplace is recommended. High load situation, physical overload is likely to appear. Workplace redesign is necessary.

Posture Trunk upright, not twisted Trunk slightly bending forward or slightly twisted (onesided pulling) Body inclined low in direction of motion Squatting, kneeling, bending Combination of bending and twisting
Positioning accuracy: Low \n-no specification of travelling distance \n- load can roll to a stop or runs against a stop High \n- Load must be accurately positioned and stopped \n- Travelling distance must be adhered to exactly\n- Frequent changes in direction
Speed of motion: slow (less than 0.8m/s) fast (0.8 bis 1.3 m/s)
Working conditions Good, floor or other surfaces level, firm, smooth, dry; no incline; no obstacles in workspace; rollers or wheels run easily, no evident wear in the wheel bearings. Restricted, floor soiled, a little uneven, soft; slight incline up to 2°; obstacles in workspace which have to be bypassed; rollers or wheels soiled, no longer run easily, bearings worn. Difficult, unpaved or roughly paved roadway, potholes, severe soiling; inclines of 2 to 5°; industrial trucks have to be torn loose when starting up; rollers or wheels soiled, bearings. Complicated, steps, stairs ! inclines >5°; combinations of indicators from "restricted" to "difficult" run sluggishly.
Low load situation, physical overload unlikely to appear. Increased load situation, physical overload is possible for less resilent persons. For that group redesign of workplace is helpful. Highly increased load situation, physical overload also possible for normal persons. Redesign of the workplace is recommended. High load situation, physical overload is likely to appear. Workplace redesign is necessary.
/////////////////////////////////////////MAC///////////////////////////////////
Is to assess the most common risk factors in operations elevation (up and down), and transport (press and hold).
Load weight/frequency
0
4
6
10
Rating The value chosen must be based on the load weight netre relationship graph with time of elevation or elevations per hour. Graphis:
Hand distance from the lower back
CLOSE\n -Upper arms aligned vertically and upright trunk MODERATE\n -Upper arms angled away from body MODERATE\n -Trunk bent forward FAR\n -Upper arms angled away from body and trunk bent forward
Vertical lift region Above knee and/or below elbow height Below knee and/or above elbow height Floor level or below; At head height or above
Trunk twisting and sideways bending Little or no twisting or sideways bending If the trunk twists in relation to the hips and thighs \nor the operative leans to one side as the load is lifted If the trunk both twists AND bends to the side as the load is lifted
Postural constraints If the movements of the operative are unhindered If the operative adopts restricted postures during the lift because of the space available, \ne.g. a narrow gap between pallet load and hopper, or the workstation design e.g. an excessively high monorail conveyor. If the posture is severely restricted \neg work in confined areas such as baggage holds
Grip on the load GOOD\n -Containers with welldesigned handles or handholds, fit for purpose\n - Loose parts enabling comfortable grip REASONABLE\n -Containers with poor handles or handholds\n -Fingers to be clamped at 90 degrees under the container POOR\n -Containers of poor design.\n -Loose parts, irregular objects, bulky or difficult to handle\n -Non-rigid sacks or unpredictable loads
Floor surface Dry and clean floor in good condition Dry floor but in poor condition, worn or uneven Contaminated/wet or steep sloping floor or unstable footing
Other environmental factors Observe the work environment and score if the lifting operation takes place:\n -in extremes of temperature\n -Fortes correntes de ar \nwith strong air movements: \n -in extreme dark conditions\n -bright or poor contrast Number of the risk factors: None Ona many
//TRANSPORTE
Carry distance 2m to 4m 4m to 10m 10m or more
Obstacles en route Risk factors:\nIf the operator has to carry a load up a steep slope, up steps, through closed doors or around tripping hazards, Trip hazards or steps\nIf the task involves carrying the load up ladders
None 1 factor 2 factors more than e 2
If the movements of the operative are unhindered If the operative adopts restricted postures during the carry\n e.g. a narrow doorway making the operative turn or move the load to get through If the posture is severely restricted \neg carrying loads in a forward bent posture in areas with low ceilings such as cellars
//EQUIPA
Number of person Load weight
2 person
3 person
4 person
Less than 35Kg
Of 35Kg to 50Kg
Of 50Kg to 85Kg
More than 85Kg
Less than 40Kg
Of 40Kg to 75Kg
Of 75Kg to 125Kg
More than 125Kg
Of 40Kg to 100Kg
Of 100Kg to 170Kg
More than 170Kg
Communication, co-ordination and control Communication between the operatives is essential when lifting as part of a team.\nExamples of good communication would be that you may hear the operatives counting 'one, two, three' etc prior to the lift.\nLook to see if the team have control of the load, that it is lifted smoothly, and that all members lift together. \nAn uncoordinated team lift may leave one member of the team bearing the entire weight. Communication points
Good Communication
REASONABLE Communication
Poor Communication
If the movements of the operative are unhindered If the operative adopts restricted postures during the carry\n e.g. narrow space between team members \nor the workstation design e.g an excessively high monorail conveyor If the posture is severely restricted \neg work in confined areas such as baggage holds
